EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into the extreme southern Panhandle, South Plains, and the Rolling Plains during the evening of the 1st as a weak upper level disturbance translated into the Southern Plains.  This boundary provided a focus for thunderstorm development.  Deep moisture, weak wind fields aloft, and slow-moving, training cells contributed to locally heavy rainfall through late evening.  Two bands of three to five inch rainfall amounts were observed: one along a Muleshoe-Dimmitt-Happy line and the other along a Lamesa-Jayton-Guthrie line.  A two to four inch band fell along a Denver City-Lubbock-Crosbyton line.  This heavy rainfall occurred over a several hour period and resulted in widespread flooding.
SUV hit bridge and flipped into local bayou. Witnesses unsuccessfully tried to save occupant.
A Jefferson County DD6 mesonet gauge located 1 mile east-northeast of Hamshire measured a six-hour rainfall total of 5.04 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved across coastal southeast Texas during the evening hours on April 18, with strong winds and numerous reports of flash flooding received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County DD6 mesonet gauge located 1 mile east-northeast of Fannett measured a six-hour rainfall total of 5.43 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved across coastal southeast Texas during the evening hours on April 18, with strong winds and numerous reports of flash flooding received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County DD6 Mesonet gauge located 2 miles west of Hamshire measured a six-hour rainfall total of 5.71 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved across coastal southeast Texas during the evening hours on April 18, with strong winds and numerous reports of flash flooding received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County DD6 mesonet gauge located 1 mile east-northeast of Fannett measured a three-hour rainfall total of 5.12 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved across coastal southeast Texas during the evening hours on April 18, with strong winds and numerous reports of flash flooding received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County DD6 Mesonet gauge located 2 miles west of Hamshire measured a three-hour rainfall total of 5.28 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved across coastal southeast Texas during the evening hours on April 18, with strong winds and numerous reports of flash flooding received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County DD6 Mesonet Station measured 4.29 inches of rainfall in approximately 3 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving eastward across southeast Texas caused numerous showers and thunderstorms to develop during the morning hours.  Numerous reports of flash flooding were received as several inches of rain fell over the entire region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Eastex Freeway service road between East Lucas and Delaware was flooded due heavy rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy Rain causes flooding in portions of Southeast Texas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains weakened the root system of a large tree causing it to collapse.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters and lines of storms produced hail and flooding. In addition several homes and one individual were struck by lightning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused some street flooding near the intersection of Beltway 8 and Interstate 45.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture combined with upper level disturbances produced some severe thunderstorms and some localized heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water on roads in and around Bonney.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving storm system and associated frontal boundary generated heavy rainfall that led to flooding across portions of southeast Texas, especially in and around the Houston and Galveston areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain (an estimated three inches) from a slow moving thunderstorm produced localized street flooding.  There was up to two feet of water over the road along Avenue D in Katy.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud developed early in the morning, then isolated severe thunderstorms formed in the early evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was high water observed near the intersection of Beltway 8 and JFK Boulevard.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed ahead of an approaching summer cold frontal boundary. Storms were enhanced by passing shortwave disturbances while interacting with outflow boundaries from sea breeze-initiated thunderstorms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall has caused some road flooding at the intersection of Bay Area Boulevard and Space Center Boulevard.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms moved into southeast Texas from the north.  Outflow boundaries with this activity in combination with deep moisture levels riding northward from the coast generated strong to severe storms across the area that lead to some wind damage, small hail and localized flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused some flooding at the intersection of Pasadena Freeway 225 and Bearle Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms moved into southeast Texas from the north.  Outflow boundaries with this activity in combination with deep moisture levels riding northward from the coast generated strong to severe storms across the area that lead to some wind damage, small hail and localized flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains (up to four inches) and some street flooding was reported in and around the La Marque area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a cold front led to heavy rainfall and localized flooding over portions of the area. A swath of four and seven inches of rain fell from Brazoria County to Chambers County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some street flooding resulted from three inches of rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training showers and thunderstorms associated with a southern plains storm system generated some heavy rainfall and a funnel cloud.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 3.32 inches of rain recorded in one hour at a Harris County Flood Control District rain gauge located at the intersection of Horsepen Bayou and Bay Area Boulevard.
A 20 x 20 foot portion of the Moody Compress Warehouse collapsed due to accumulated rain on the roof.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The weight of rain on top of a section of a warehouse roof caused it to collapse.
